thread.title: Hawaii sending wet weather this way that may stick around
thread.title_full: Hawaii sending wet weather this way that may stick around | The Seattle Times

author: Jack Broom
title: Hawaii sending wet weather this way that may stick around
text:
If you miss your rainy Seattle, this may be the forecast you’ve been waiting for:
After a couple more sunny days and high temperatures in the 80-degree neighborhood, the Puget Sound area could face its most extended damp stretch in months.
A weather system carrying moisture from the Hawaiian Islands is expected to move into the Northwest on Friday, the first of a succession of storms that could produce more than an inch of rain in the Seattle area through Saturday night, said Danny Mercer, National Weather Service meteorologist.
Precipitation is expected to change over to showers Sunday, before another system hits Monday in a wet pattern that “may persist into Tuesday or even longer,” Mercer said.
 High temperatures from Saturday through early next week “may struggle to reach 70,” Mercer said.
The Weather Channel, in a forecast issued Tuesday afternoon, put the chance of rain in Seattle at 60 percent Friday, 100 percent Saturday and 60 to 70 percent for each of the succeeding four days.
East of the Cascades, a series of showers beginning Wednesday night won’t likely bring enough rain to extinguish mammoth wildfires but could help crews trying to contain them, said Andrew Kalin, National Weather Service meteorologist in Spokane.
Those showers could offer another benefit, providing at least a temporary respite from the choking smoke that has blanketed much of Central and Eastern Washington, Kalin said.
Seattle-Tacoma International Airport hasn’t seen back-to-back days of measurable rain since June 1 and 2 and hasn’t had three straight days of measurable rain since mid-May.
The cooler pattern could linger, according to the Weather Service’s Climate Prediction Center, which projects temperatures below normal and rainfall above normal for at least the next two weeks in Western Washington.
Matt Rosencrans of the Climate Prediction Center said a trough of low pressure is shaping up over the Northwest Coast that sets the stage for more moist cold fronts coming in from the Pacific.
If the forecasts hold, Seattle’s August would slip off the stage meeker and weaker than when it arrived.
In fact, the 92-degree high at Sea-Tac on Aug. 1 has been the month’s only day in the 90s, and comes after a July that had 10 days in the 90s and went into the books as the hottest month ever recorded in Seattle.
Jack Broom: jbroom@seattletimes.com or 206-464-2222
